awd_titl_txt: 13th International Workshop on High-pT Physics in the RHIC/LHC Era; March 19-23, 2019 at the University of Tennessee Knoxville.
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides support for students to participate in the 13th International Workshop on High-pT Physics in the RHIC/LHC Era, devoted to the study of partonic energy loss in the Quark Gluon Plasma (QGP), which is a state of matter thought to have existed shortly after the Big Bang. This topic is particularly interesting now, as the field adapts from a discovery phase of the QGP to the phase where the quantitative properties of the medium are determined. The workshops in this series are intended to provide an informal forum in which theorists, experimentalists, senior researchers, and junior researchers interact and learn from each other. The workshop will take place at the University of Tennessee in Knoxville, TN, March 19 - 23, 2019. 

Undergraduate students will also present their research and the PI will discuss her course-based undergraduate research experience with applications to partonic energy loss in the QGP.  This will not only highlight undergraduate researchers but propose a model for how other researchers can incorporate undergraduates into their research and broaden participation in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 13th International Workshop on High-pT Physics in the RHIC/LHC Era Mar. 19-22 in Knoxville, TN was the most recent in a series of workshops designed to be affordable and enable a robust discussion of the physics of partonic energy loss in the Quark Gluon Plasma. One of the main criteria in site selection and conference organization is affordability in order to enable junior members of the community to attend and interact extensively with experts in this field. There were 36 speakers, 9 (25%) of whom were women. We were able to cover registration fees for 15 attendees (5 women) and lodging costs for 8 attendees (4 women) using $6,028 from the NSF combined with the surplus from registration fees from senior participants. All attendees supported were students or postdoctoral researchers. These awards allowed greater participation of students and postdoctoral researchers in the workshop.

In addition to the workshop, we held a lunch for minorities in physics with Edmundo Garcia from Chicago State, a lunch for women in physics with Barbara Jacak from Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, and a lunch with Edmundo Garcia and the University of Tennessee, Knoxville physics department diversity task force, benefitting from Jacak and Garcia’s attendance at the ALICE USA meeting. The lunches were open to people in the ALICE collaboration and the UTK physics department. About six undergraduate and graduate students attended the lunch for minorities in physics and about ten students and post-doctoral researchers attended the lunch for women in physics.
